info: Forests are primarily cleared for cattle ranching, farming, and logging, accelerating climate change and disrupting ecosystems globally.
Globally, 1.25 billion people depend on forests for food, water, shelter, and fuel.
The global rate of deforestation decreased from 16 million hectares a year in the 1990s to 10 million hectares a year between 2015 and 2020.
Despite a downward trend in deforestation, the Brazilian Amazon saw a record 64% increase in deforestation (941 sq km) in the first quarter of 2022.
Scientists predict the Amazon Rainforest may reach a tipping point, releasing 90 billion metric tons of CO2 if 20-25% of the rainforest is lost. We are approaching 20%.
The rate of species extinction is estimated to be 1,000 to 10,000 times greater than without human influence.
Between 1970 and 2020, populations of mammals, fish, birds, reptiles, and amphibians decreased by an average of 68%.
In a sample of 177 mammal species, all 177 had lost at least 30% of their geographic range.
Insect abundance is decreasing at a rate of 1%-2% annually, with some terrestrial regions experiencing losses of over 10% each decade.
At least 800 marine species are threatened by ocean debris, mostly plastic, causing suffocation and starvation in species like sea turtles.
A third of all marine animals could go extinct in the next 300 years if greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise.
Since the 1950s, half of all living corals have died, and 99% of coral reefs may die within 10 years without drastic carbon emission reduction measures.
In 2021, global carbon dioxide emissions reached their highest level ever, contributing to climate change and extreme weather events.
Tropical forests absorb 1.4 billion metric tons of CO2, and globally, forests remove up to 30% of the CO2 emitted by humans.
While 80% of overall energy production worldwide comes from fossil fuels, renewable sources like solar and wind energy now account for 29% of electricity.
Even low levels of air pollution increase the risk of various health issues, including heart disease, stroke, and premature death.
97.3% of the world's population is exposed to an unsafe amount of air pollution, according to World Health Organization guidelines.
Conservation efforts face challenges in government and the Supreme Court, despite evidence that a cleaner world improves health and fights injustice.
The U.S. House passed a new wildlife conservation fund, the Biden administration launched a conservation program, and scientists are developing clean energy and carbon capture technology.
